awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Forecasting & Communicating the US Fall/Winter Respiratory Disease Outlook
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop new models and forecasts of COVID, influenza, and RSV incidence and severity for the 2023/2024 season. The project will test a new approach to public health forecasting by combining computational models with human judgment. For the first time on a national scale, it will bring together computational modeling and human forecasting, seeking to improve forecasting accuracy and responsiveness. Additionally, it will boost public trust and transparency by introducing innovative communication methods to clearly convey risk and uncertainty. The project will bolster the preparedness of the Center for the 2023/2024 respiratory disease season through the delivery of weekly forecasts, analysis, and communication support. Public communication will be delivered via data dashboards prepared by the CDC and populated with project forecasts, as well as weekly written updates that together will provide a comprehensive, regularly updated, probabilistic outlook on the expected timing, severity, and peaks of COVID, influenza, and RSV. In close collaboration with the CDC, the project will craft tailored visual and verbal communication strategies, emphasizing forecast confidence.

This proposal investigates the potential of frequent, probabilistic forecasting and related public communication to improve nationwide public health preparedness during the peak respiratory disease season, building on successful state-level epidemiological response and planning efforts from 2020-2023. The project will operate a public forecasting tournament to provide numerical forecasts for use in communicating and quantifying the expected fall and winter respiratory disease burden of RSV, influenza, and COVID. It will work closely with the CDC to create forecasting questions for the tournament. Questions focused on the timing and magnitude of the peak onset of respiratory illnesses will help chart the expected trajectory, while other questions may track vaccine uptake, week-by-week disease burden, the potential for emerging variants, and the risk of high hospital utilization. In collaboration with the CDC, it also will explore the potential for forecasting questions that could be used to enhance existing CDC modeling through human judgment and parameterization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Respiratory Outlook 2023/24 project pioneered an innovative approach to predicting national public health outcomes through human judgment forecasting. Timely and accurate forecasts that respond and adapt to current needs can be of great use to policy-makers. By leveraging a community of expert forecasters through Metaculus, an online prediction platform, the Respiratory Outlook 2023/24 project delivered weekly forecasts of over 75 key epidemiological indicators to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Forecasts included numerical predictions as well as qualitative reasoning, clearly communicating and contextualizing the likelihood of various public health scenarios. 


The project demonstrated that human judgment forecasting can provide accurate predictions, in particular in rapidly evolving and complex situations where traditional modeling methods may be insufficient due to their limited ability to encode qualitative human judgement. Regular comparisons revealed that human judgement forecasts on Metaculus achieved comparable accuracy to CDC's ensemble models while also informing decision-makers on topics where forecasts based on traditional modeling were unavailable. Based on these results, CDC extended the collaboration into the subsequent season through a separate NSF grant, expanding to incorporate an expert elicitation process.


All forecasting questions, predictions and rationales were made publicly available. This allowed the greater public to engage with current public health questions and participate in forecasting key respiratory disease outcomes. Participants and visitors to the site gained firsthand experience interpreting health data and understanding its implications, strengthening overall data literacy. By openly sharing forecasts and reasoning, the project contributed to a transparent and fact-based public health communication. Ultimately, Respiratory Outlook 2023/24 demonstrated the potential of crowd-sourced forecasting as an effective tool for supporting public health preparedness and decision-making at the national level.
